On Thu, 6 Feb 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Pushing every SQL statement you use out to a ResourceBundle (or other
> metadata file) is a good idea.

Eww! I know this tends to be a bit of a personal preference, but I far
prefer to keep my code together when I can. If a statement is used in
only one place, keeping it where it's used makes the code much easier to
read, because you don't have to go chasing off into some other file to
find out what SQL statement is being executed.

> It's very easy to write a single test
> that runs through all the SQL statements in the metadata file and do a
> sanity check on them: can I read the columns from the tables I SELECT?
> and so on.

Well, for the simple stuff, why bother? If I have a method like:

    public void setCount(int count) {
	if (count == _count)
	    return;
	DB.update("UPDATE mytable SET count = ? WHERE id = ?",
	    new Object() { new Integer(_id), new Integer(_count), });
	_count = count;
    }

Doesn't it seem like a lot more work to move that statement out to a
separate file than just to test the whole method with a single test?

And as for the more complex stuff, I don't think that it's going to
be very useful to test separately a bunch of statements that need to
execute in order as one transaction. You still need to test the whole
transaction, and that will test the individual statements anyway.
